cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTVS GOVERNMENTPrinted for the Cabinet. January 1939.SECRET. Copy No.CP. 18(39).CABINET.PALESTINE. Memorandum by the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. I HAD intended to circulate to my colleagues, before the opening of thediscussions on Palestine policy with the Arab and Jewish delegates who are about to assemble in London, a memorandum setting forth how the problemsat issue are regarded from the point of view of our general foreign relations. 2. I have now, however, bad the opportunity of reading the memorandum(Cabinet Paper No. 4'(39)) circulated by the Secretary of State for the Colonies,and I feel that his paper gives all the material necessary for our deliberationsin Cabinet and the Cabinet Committee on Palestine. 3. It is perhaps inevitable that I should look at the Palestine problem from a slightly different angle from that in which it presents itself to the colonial secretary. And I should not wish my colleagues to assume that I am in full agreement with the memorandum on every point, or that I endorse all the opinions expressed therein, although I gratefully acknowledge the place that the colonial secretary, in the preparation of his paper, has given to the considerations whichit has been my duty to bring to his notice. I am moreover very glad to see,from paragraph 53 of the Colonial Secretary's memorandum, that on the onequestion of substantial importance regarding which he and I are at presentinclined to take different views, namely, the question how far in the last resortwe should go to meet the Arab delegates in the matter of future Jewish immigration into Palestine, he is prepared for the present not to press for a final decision. 4. In these circumstances, I do not propose, unless my colleagues instructme to do so, to circulate a paper regarding Palestine policy in its relation toforeign affairs and our foreign policy as a whole. H. January 23, 1939.10230 [18540]
